`pkg/tui/models/up.go` and `pkg/tui/models/down.go` currently call `tea.Quit` when:
- user declines/cancels confirmation
- flow reaches complete
- user exits error state

## Pattern Reference
```go
func (m *LsMonitor) startNodesPoller() <-chan []views.NodeInfo {
    updates := make(chan []views.NodeInfo, 1)

    go func() {
        defer close(updates)
        ticker := time.NewTicker(m.config.NodesRefreshInterval)
        defer ticker.Stop()

        // Initial fetch
        if nodes, err := m.fetchNodes(); err == nil {
            updates <- nodes
        }

        for {
            select {
            case <-m.ctx.Done():
                return
            case <-ticker.C:
                if nodes, err := m.fetchNodes(); err == nil {
                    updates <- nodes
                }
            }
        }
    }()

    return updates
}
```

- [ ] Initial data fetched immediately on start
- [ ] Pollers respect context cancellation

title: Bubble Tea: stop mutating model state inside tea.Cmd
description:
## Problem
Several Bubble Tea models mutate their own fields inside `tea.Cmd` functions. Bubble Tea runs cmds asynchronously, so this pattern can race with `Update()`/`View()` and is generally unsafe.

Examples:
- `pkg/tui/models/app.go:142` (`initializeSubModels`) mutates `m.dashboardModel`, `m.downModel`, `m.upModel`, and `m.initialized` from inside a command.
- `pkg/tui/models/dashboard.go:121` (`startMonitorCmd`) assigns `m.monitor` and starts it inside a command.

## Impact
- Potential data races and undefined behavior (even if not always detected by `-race`).
- Hard-to-reproduce UI glitches (partial/incorrect state, nil deref on racey reads).

## Proposed Fix
Adopt the Bubble Tea rule of thumb: **cmds return messages; only `Update()` mutates model state**.

Concrete approaches:
- Change cmd functions to construct new objects and return them in a message, e.g.:
  - `SubModelsInitializedMsg{Down: *DownModel, Up: *UpModel, ...}`
  - `DashboardMonitorStartedMsg{Monitor: *monitoring.Monitor, Initial: *monitoring.MonitorUpdate}`
- In `Update()`, assign fields and start subsequent cmds.

## Dependencies / Ordering
- Recommended before wiring the real `DashboardModel` into `AppModel`.

## Acceptance Criteria
- No writes to model fields from inside `tea.Cmd` closures across `pkg/tui/models/*`.
- `go test -race ./...` passes (after fixing known failing races).
- Add/adjust tests where needed to cover initialization and monitor start/stop flows.

title: HeaderFetcher: propagate cancellation to fetch commands
description:
## Problem
`HeaderFetcher` has a cancelable context (`f.ctx`/`f.cancel`) but does not actually use it for fetches.

- `pkg/tui/components/header_fetcher.go:41` uses `context.Background()` in `HeaderFetchCmd`, so `Stop()` does not cancel in-flight fetches.
- `Start()` initializes `f.ctx` but the ctx isn’t passed to fetch cmds.

## Impact
- In-flight k8s calls continue after the UI/model is “stopped”.
- Makes graceful shutdown/cancel behavior unreliable.

## Proposed Fix
- Make the fetch cmd accept and use the fetcher’s context:
  - e.g. `func HeaderFetchCmd(ctx context.Context, client *k8s.Client, namespace string) tea.Cmd`
  - use `ctx` in `FetchClusterHeaderData`.
- Ensure `HandleTick()` doesn’t schedule more work after cancellation.

## Tests
- Add a test that `Stop()` prevents future ticks from scheduling fetches.
- If practical, add a test with a blocking fake client call and verify cancellation via context.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `Stop()` reliably halts future fetch scheduling and cancels in-flight fetches.
- No `context.Background()` used for cancellable background operations.
close_reason: Fixed by commit 16471d2. Added context parameter to HeaderFetchCmd and propagated the fetcher's cancelable context to all fetch calls.

title: ProgressBar: prevent negative width panic
description:
## Problem
`ProgressBar.renderDeterminate()` can compute a negative `barWidth` and then panic when calling `strings.Repeat`.

- `pkg/tui/components/progress.go:130`–`pkg/tui/components/progress.go:146`
- With `ShowPercentage=true` and `Width < 5`, `barWidth -= 5` becomes negative.

## Impact
- TUI can crash on narrow terminals or if width is set incorrectly.

## Proposed Fix
- Clamp `barWidth` to a minimum after reserving percentage space.
- Add a regression test for small widths.

## Acceptance Criteria
- No panic for any `Width` value (including 0, 1..4) with `ShowPercentage=true`.
- Unit test covers the small-width cases.
close_reason: Fixed by commit 992bba9. Added clamp after percentage subtraction to ensure barWidth is always at least 1, preventing strings.Repeat panic on small widths.

title: Down/Up TUIs: wire progress callbacks + cancellation
description:
## Problem
Down/Up TUIs define progress message types/state transitions, but the long-running operations never emit those messages.

- `pkg/tui/models/down.go:224` sets `ProgressCallback` but the callback is a no-op.
- `pkg/tui/models/up.go:277` sets `ProgressCallback` but the callback is a no-op.

Additional UX/correctness problems:
- Cancel handling is UI-only (e.g. ctrl+c triggers `tea.Quit`) but does not guarantee the underlying maintenance context is canceled.
- `UpModel.startExecution()` sets `state = UpStateRestoringDeployments` immediately (even though the first real stage is uncordon).

## Impact
- Operator sees a mostly static UI during maintenance operations.
- Harder to diagnose where an operation is stuck.
- Risk of background goroutine continuing after UI exits.

## Proposed Fix
- Stream progress into Bubble Tea via a channel + “listen cmd” pattern:
  - operation goroutine writes progress messages to a channel
  - model schedules a cmd that blocks on `<-ch` and returns the next msg, then reschedules until channel closes
- Use a cancelable context owned by the model:
  - `ctx, cancel := context.WithCancel(m.config.Context)`
  - on ctrl+c / quit, call `cancel()` before exiting.
- Align UI stage mapping with actual maintenance stages.

## Acceptance Criteria
- UI status list advances through stages during Down/Up.
- Cancel (ctrl+c) cancels in-flight work and does not leak goroutines.
- Tests cover progress message plumbing and state transitions.
close_reason: Fixed by commit 916cd5d. Implemented progress channel streaming and proper cancellation for Down/Up TUI models.

title: crook ls TUI: surface fetch errors and partial-data state
description:
## Problem
`LsModel.fetchDataCmd()` silently ignores most data-fetch errors and never surfaces them to the user.

- `pkg/tui/models/ls.go:203`–`pkg/tui/models/ls.go:324` overwrites `err` repeatedly and only assigns fields when `err == nil`.
- `LsDataLoadedMsg.Error` exists but is never populated.
- `LsModel.lastError` is set but never rendered.

## Impact
- Users see empty/partial data with no explanation.

## Proposed Fix
- Capture and surface errors:
  - If any fetch fails, set `result.Error` (aggregate errors; or store per-section errors).
  - Render an error banner/status line in `View()` when `lastError != nil`.
  - Decide whether partial data is acceptable; if yes, show “partial data” + which sections failed.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Errors during fetch are visible in the TUI.
- Refresh (`r`) reports failures instead of silently doing nothing.
- Tests cover error propagation/rendering.

title: crook ls TUI: fix Esc filter behavior (model/view sync)
description:
## Problem
In `crook ls` filter mode, pressing Esc clears `m.filter` but does not propagate the cleared filter to the views.

- `pkg/tui/models/ls.go:515`–`pkg/tui/models/ls.go:518`

After Esc:
- `m.filter` becomes ""
- but views still hold the last applied filter until Enter is pressed in a later filter session.

## Impact
- UI state becomes inconsistent.

## Proposed Fix
Pick a consistent filter UX contract:
- Option A: Esc exits filter input and restores the previously applied filter.
- Option B: Esc clears filter and immediately applies the clear to views.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Esc behavior is consistent and leaves model+views in sync.
- Add regression test in `pkg/tui/models/ls_test.go`.

title: TUI rendering: fix unicode/ANSI width + truncation
description:
## Problem
Multiple renderers truncate/pad using `len()` and raw slicing, which breaks:
- multi-byte Unicode characters
- strings styled with ANSI escape codes (lipgloss)

Examples:
- `pkg/tui/components/detail.go:525` truncates rendered lines via `line[:contentWidth-3]`
- `pkg/tui/views/*` use `len()`/slicing for truncation and fixed padding
- `pkg/tui/components/table.go` uses `len()` to compute widths and truncation

## Impact
- Corrupted output (broken glyphs, broken escape sequences).
- Misaligned tables under styling.

## Proposed Fix
- Use `lipgloss.Width`, `lipgloss.Truncate`, and/or strip ANSI for width calculations.
- Centralize truncation/padding helpers.

## Acceptance Criteria
- No broken ANSI sequences from truncation.
- Rendering remains aligned with unicode icons enabled.
- Add tests for truncation behavior where practical.

title: Dashboard: route to real model + fix NextRoute sentinel
description:
## Problem
There is a real `DashboardModel` implementation, but `AppModel` still routes `RouteDashboard` to a placeholder model.

- `pkg/tui/models/app.go:143`–`pkg/tui/models/app.go:147`

Also, `DashboardModel` uses `NextRoute != 0` as a sentinel for “has next route”, which collides with `RouteDashboard == 0`.
- `pkg/tui/models/dashboard.go:203`–`pkg/tui/models/dashboard.go:207`

## Impact
- Dashboard code is effectively dead/unreachable.
- `NextRoute` can’t safely target `RouteDashboard` and the sentinel logic is fragile.

## Proposed Fix
- Wire `NewDashboardModel` into `RouteDashboard`.
- Replace the `NextRoute != 0` sentinel with an explicit boolean or pointer.
- Ensure monitor lifecycle is clean (stop on quit/route change) and consistent with Bubble Tea cmd safety patterns.

## Dependencies
- Should be done after (or alongside) “no model mutation inside tea.Cmd”.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `RouteDashboard` shows the real dashboard view.
- Proceed routing works for all routes without sentinel collisions.
- Monitor is stopped on exit/route change.

- Proposal: `openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/proposal.md`

title: Refactor LsModel for multi-pane rendering
description:
Major refactor of the LsModel to display all three panes simultaneously instead of tab-based single-view navigation.

## Context

This is the core implementation task. The current `LsModel` uses `TabBar` to switch between single views. The refactor replaces this with a multi-pane layout where all three resource types (Nodes, Deployments/Pods, OSDs) are visible simultaneously in stacked rows.

## Implementation Details

**File to modify:** `pkg/tui/models/ls.go`

### 1. Replace Tab System with Pane System

**Replace enum:**
```go
// OLD
type LsTab int
const (
    LsTabNodes LsTab = iota
    LsTabDeployments
    LsTabOSDs
    LsTabPods
)

// NEW
type LsPane int
const (
    LsPaneNodes LsPane = iota
    LsPaneDeployments  // Also handles pods toggle
    LsPaneOSDs
)
```

**Update LsModel struct:**
```go
type LsModel struct {
    // ... existing fields ...
    
    // REMOVE: tabBar *components.TabBar
    
    // ADD:
    activePane          LsPane
    panes               [3]*components.Pane
    deploymentsPodsView *views.DeploymentsPodsView  // Replaces separate views
}
```

### 2. Update NewLsModel Constructor

- Create 3 Pane components instead of TabBar
- Create DeploymentsPodsView wrapper
- Initialize activePane to LsPaneNodes
- Set up pane configs with titles and shortcut keys

### 3. Update handleKeyPress()

**New key bindings:**
```go
case "tab":
    m.nextPane()  // Cycle: Nodes -> Deps -> OSDs -> Nodes
case "shift+tab":
    m.prevPane()  // Cycle backwards
case "1":
    m.setActivePane(LsPaneNodes)
case "2":
    m.setActivePane(LsPaneDeployments)
case "3":
    m.setActivePane(LsPaneOSDs)
case "[":
    if m.activePane == LsPaneDeployments {
        m.deploymentsPodsView.ShowDeployments()
    }
case "]:
    if m.activePane == LsPaneDeployments {
        m.deploymentsPodsView.ShowPods()
    }
```

**Cursor navigation only affects active pane:**
- j/k, up/down should only move cursor in the active pane
- Other panes retain their cursor positions

### 4. Update View() for Multi-Pane Rendering

```go
func (m *LsModel) View() string {
    var b strings.Builder
    
    // Header (unchanged)
    b.WriteString(m.header.View())
    b.WriteString("\n\n")
    
    // Pane navigation bar (replaces tab bar)
    b.WriteString(m.renderPaneNavBar())
    b.WriteString("\n\n")
    
    // Calculate height distribution
    availableHeight := m.height - headerHeight - navBarHeight - statusBarHeight
    activeHeight := availableHeight / 2      // 50%
    inactiveHeight := availableHeight / 4    // 25% each
    
    // Render all three panes
    for i, pane := range m.panes {
        isActive := LsPane(i) == m.activePane
        height := inactiveHeight
        if isActive {
            height = activeHeight
        }
        
        // Set size on view and get content
        content := m.getViewContent(LsPane(i), height)
        
        // Wrap in pane with appropriate styling
        pane.SetActive(isActive)
        pane.SetSize(m.width, height)
        b.WriteString(pane.View(content))
        b.WriteString("\n")
    }
    
    // Status bar with context-sensitive hints
    b.WriteString(m.renderStatusBar())
    
    return b.String()
}
```

### 5. Update Status Bar

Show toggle hint only when deployments pane is active:
```go
func (m *LsModel) renderStatusBar() string {
    hints := []string{"Tab/1-3: pane", "j/k: navigate"}
    if m.activePane == LsPaneDeployments {
        hints = append(hints, "[/]: deps/pods")
    }
    hints = append(hints, "/: filter", "?: help", "q: quit")
    return styles.StyleSubtle.Render(strings.Join(hints, "  "))
}
```

### 6. Update Help Overlay

Update keyboard shortcuts in help overlay to reflect new navigation.

### 7. Helper Methods to Add

- `nextPane()` - Cycle to next pane
- `prevPane()` - Cycle to previous pane  
- `setActivePane(pane LsPane)` - Direct pane selection
- `renderPaneNavBar() string` - Render navigation bar with badges
- `getViewContent(pane LsPane, height int) string` - Get view content at specified height

## Dependencies

- Requires: crook-2l4.1 (pane styles)
- Requires: crook-2l4.2 (Pane component)
- Requires: crook-2l4.3 (DeploymentsPodsView)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All three panes visible simultaneously
- [ ] Active pane gets 50% height, inactive panes get 25% each
- [ ] Tab/Shift+Tab cycles through panes
- [ ] 1/2/3 keys directly select panes
- [ ] `[` and `]` toggle deployments/pods in middle pane
- [ ] Cursor navigation only affects active pane
- [ ] Status bar shows context-sensitive hints
- [ ] Help overlay updated with new keybindings
- [ ] Filter still applies to all views
- [ ] Existing table content unchanged (columns, rendering)
- [ ] All tests pass
- [ ] Code passes linting

title: P0: Fix RBAC SelfSubjectAccessReview checks for maintenance
description:
## Problem
`pkg/maintenance/validator.go` builds `SelfSubjectAccessReview` requests that are very likely incorrect for real clusters:
- Uses `ResourceAttributes.Resource` values like `"pods/exec"` instead of `Resource="pods"` + `Subresource="exec"`.
- Omits API group (e.g. `apps` for deployments), so checks can be evaluated against the wrong group.
- Always sets `Namespace` (using rook cluster namespace) even for cluster-scoped resources like `nodes`.

This can cause false negatives that block `crook down` during pre-flight, or false positives that allow proceeding and failing later.

## Evidence
- `pkg/maintenance/validator.go:152` (permission list)
- `pkg/maintenance/validator.go:200` (SAR construction)
- Spec requires RBAC validation: `openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/specs/node-maintenance/spec.md:91`

## Proposed Fix
- Extend permission tuples to include `group`, `resource`, `subresource`, and whether the check is namespaced.
- Construct SARs with correct fields:
  - `Group: "apps"`, `Resource: "deployments"`, `Verb: "get"|"update"` (and/or `Subresource: "scale"` depending on implementation)
  - `Resource: "pods"`, `Subresource: "exec"`, `Verb: "create"`
  - `Resource: "nodes"`, `Verb: "patch"`, `Namespace: ""`
- Add missing required permissions for discovery/ownership traversal (ReplicaSets get), or change discovery to avoid needing them.
- Decide how to handle SAR failures:
  - If SAR request errors (API not enabled / permission denied to create SAR), treat as warning (not pass) and surface clearly.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Pre-flight RBAC checks match actual Kubernetes operations performed by maintenance code.
- Running `crook down` in a cluster with correct RBAC no longer fails pre-flight due to incorrect SAR construction.
- Unit tests cover:
  - group/subresource handling
  - cluster-scoped vs namespaced resources

title: state: backup filenames can collide + use invalid characters
description:
Problem
- `pkg/state/backup.go:49` uses `time.RFC3339` for the backup filename timestamp (1s resolution and includes `:`).
- Two backups in the same second (or concurrent invocations) can fail at `pkg/state/backup.go:92` with `EEXIST` because `os.O_EXCL` is used.
- `:` in filenames is invalid on Windows, and can be awkward on some tooling.

Impact
- Backup may fail unexpectedly during repeated/parallel runs, preventing state write (depending on call site).
- Reduced portability of state backups.

Proposed Fix
- Use a collision-resistant, filesystem-safe suffix: e.g., `UnixNano` or `RFC3339Nano` with `:` sanitized, and/or add a random/pid suffix.
- Update any state-file discovery logic (CLI list/clean) if it assumes a specific backup naming scheme.

Acceptance Criteria
- Backups created in rapid succession do not collide.
- Backup names contain only portable characters (no `:`).
- Add/extend unit tests in `pkg/state/backup_test.go` to cover collision resistance.

title: spec: resolve state file permission mismatch (0644 vs 0600)
description:

Impact
- Spec mismatch; tooling/docs may mislead operators about file readability.

Proposed Resolution
- Decide desired policy:
  - Prefer `0600` (recommended: least privilege), then update spec accordingly; or
  - Change implementation to `0644` if you want other users on the machine to read state files.

Acceptance Criteria
- Spec and code agree on state file mode.
- Tests updated/added to lock behavior.

- Table includes size and a clear “old” indicator for >7d (or update spec if different UX).

title: spec: reconcile operator replicas requirement (restore saved vs force 1)

title: state: avoid leaving partial backup files on failure
description:
Problem
- `pkg/state/backup.go:100-108` can leave a partially-written backup file if `io.Copy`, `Sync`, or `Close` fails.

Notes on spec
- The State Persistence spec explicitly says *state write* temp files should be retained on failure for debugging (`openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/specs/state-persistence/spec.md`). This issue is therefore scoped to backup files only (not the atomic state-file temp).

Impact
- Partial backups may look valid to operators/tools and clutter the backup directory.

Proposed Fix
- If an error occurs after creating `dst`, best-effort remove `dst` before returning (without masking the primary error).

Acceptance Criteria
- On injected copy/sync/close failure, no partial backup file remains.
- Add/extend unit tests in `pkg/state/backup_test.go` where feasible.

title: state: improve durability by syncing parent directory after atomic rename
description:
Problem
- `pkg/state/format.go:209` replaces the destination with `os.Rename`, but does not `fsync` the containing directory afterward.

Impact
- On power loss / kernel crash, rename durability is not guaranteed on some filesystems unless the directory entry is synced.

Proposed Fix
- After successful `os.Rename`, open the parent directory and call `Sync` (best-effort; handle platforms/filesystems that don't support it).

Acceptance Criteria
- Atomic write remains atomic.
- Add a small unit/integration test where practical, or document rationale if not testable.

title: state: backups should not inherit overly-broad file permissions
description:
Problem
- `pkg/state/backup.go:65` passes `info.Mode().Perm()` into `copyFile`, so backups inherit the original state file permissions.
- If the state file is accidentally created with `0644`, backups become world-readable too.

Impact
- Potential exposure of cluster/node operational data to unintended local users.

Proposed Fix
- Force backup file mode to `0600`, or clamp to `min(srcPerm, 0600)` (never more permissive than `0600`).
- Ensure state writes already enforce `0600` (they currently `Chmod` the temp file in `pkg/state/format.go:205`).

Acceptance Criteria
- Backups are always `0600` (or stricter) regardless of source file perms.
- Add test coverage in `pkg/state/backup_test.go` validating backup mode.

title: state: harden file operations against symlink/TOCTOU issues
description:
Problem
- `ValidateFile` does `os.Stat` then `ParseFile` (`pkg/state/validation.go:32-44`), and `ParseFile` uses `os.ReadFile` (`pkg/state/format.go:39`).
- `BackupFile` does `os.Stat` then `os.Open` (`pkg/state/backup.go:29-90`).
- If an attacker can swap the target path between these calls (or use symlinks), the code may read/copy unexpected files.

Impact
- Local privilege boundary concern on multi-user systems or when state path is in a writable/shared location.

Proposed Fix Options
- Option A (simple): use `Lstat` and reject symlinks for state/backup paths.
- Option B (stronger, unix-only): open with `O_NOFOLLOW` via `golang.org/x/sys/unix` and operate via file descriptor, then validate file type.
- Decide threat model and pick approach consistent with project portability goals.

Acceptance Criteria
- Symlink targets are rejected (or safely handled) in state read/write/backup flows.
- Tests cover the chosen behavior on supported platforms.

title: state: decide on JSON schema strictness + limit read size
description:
Problem
- Parser currently allows unknown fields because `json.Decoder` does not call `DisallowUnknownFields()` (`pkg/state/format.go:100-106`). Typos or unexpected input can be silently ignored.
- `ParseFile` uses `os.ReadFile` (`pkg/state/format.go:39`), allowing unbounded read into memory.

Tradeoffs
- Strict schema catches operator mistakes but can block forward-compat if new fields are added later.

Proposed Work
- Decide desired behavior:
  - Strict: add `decoder.DisallowUnknownFields()` and bump/plan schema evolution accordingly, or
  - Lenient: keep unknown fields, but consider logging/warnings.
- Add a max-size check for state files (e.g., stat + cap to a few MiB) before reading.

Acceptance Criteria
- Explicit decision documented in code and/or docs.
- Implementation matches decision and has unit tests.

title: state: reduce side effects in ResolvePath and dedupe directory creation
description:
Problem
- `ResolvePath` / `ResolvePathWithOverride` create parent directories as a side effect (`pkg/state/path.go:37`, `pkg/state/path.go:51`).
- `writeFileAtomic` also creates directories (`pkg/state/format.go:178-183`), duplicating logic.

Impact
- Read-only flows may unexpectedly create directories (surprising behavior).
- Duplicated logic increases drift risk (perm mismatches, differing error messages).

Proposed Fix
- Split pure path resolution from directory creation, e.g.:
  - `ResolvePath(...) (string, error)` (no filesystem writes)
  - `EnsureParentDir(path) error` (explicit and used only for writes)
- Consolidate directory creation behavior (one helper, one permission strategy).
- Update call sites (`pkg/maintenance/*`, `pkg/tui/models/*`, CLI) accordingly.

Acceptance Criteria
- Path resolution does not create directories unless explicitly requested.
- All tests pass; add/update tests in `pkg/state/path_test.go` to match new semantics.

title: tui/output: fix data race found by go test -race
description:
## Problem
`go test -race ./...` reports a data race in `pkg/tui/output/watch.go`:
- write in `(*WatchRunner).Run` at `pkg/tui/output/watch.go:153`
- read in `(*WatchRunner).IsRunning` at `pkg/tui/output/watch.go:161`

Additional correctness/leak findings in the same watch implementation:
- Potential goroutine leak: `RunWatch` starts a goroutine that blocks forever on `<-sigChan` if the context is canceled without a signal; `signal.Stop` is not called.
  - `pkg/tui/output/watch.go:39`–`pkg/tui/output/watch.go:45`
- Potential panic: `time.NewTicker(opts.Interval)` panics if `opts.Interval <= 0`.
  - `pkg/tui/output/watch.go:56`

## Impact
- Test suite fails under `-race` (blocks using race detector in CI).
- Concurrency bugs and shutdown leaks in watch mode.
- Invalid `--refresh` / interval inputs can crash the process.

## Proposed Fix
1. Make `WatchRunner.running` concurrency-safe:
   - use `sync/atomic` (preferred) or `sync.Mutex` to protect reads/writes.
2. Fix signal goroutine + cleanup:
   - `defer signal.Stop(sigChan)`
   - goroutine should `select { case <-sigChan: cancel(); case <-ctx.Done(): }` to avoid leaks.
3. Validate `opts.Interval` before ticker creation:
   - return an error for `<= 0` (and consider a minimum like 1s if desired).

## Tests
- Ensure `pkg/tui/output/watch_test.go` passes under `-race`.
- Add/adjust tests for invalid intervals and clean shutdown.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `go test -race ./...` passes.
- Watch mode exits cleanly without leaking goroutines (no blocked goroutine on `sigChan`).
- `RunWatch` returns a clear error for invalid intervals instead of panicking.
close_reason:
Fixed data race and improved watch implementation:

1. Data race fix: Changed WatchRunner.running from bool to atomic.Bool
   - Uses CompareAndSwap for atomic check-and-set in Run()
   - Uses Load() for safe concurrent reads in IsRunning()

2. Signal goroutine leak fix: 
   - Added defer signal.Stop(sigChan) to properly unregister signal handler
   - Changed goroutine to use select with both <-sigChan and <-ctx.Done() cases

3. Interval validation: 
   - Returns error for interval <= 0 (prevents ticker panic)
   - Returns error for interval < MinWatchInterval (100ms minimum)

4. Added tests for invalid intervals and already-running state

All tests pass with go test -race ./pkg/tui/output/...

   func runWatch(ctx context.Context, interval time.Duration, fetchFn func() (Data, error), renderFn func(Data)) error {

       for {
           select {
           case <-ctx.Done():
               return nil
           case <-ticker.C:
               data, err := fetchFn()
               if err != nil {

               }
               clearScreen()
               renderFn(data)

   }

title: Fix cobra context propagation + signal cancellation
description:
## Context
`crook` commands should be cancellable (Ctrl+C / SIGTERM) and should propagate `context.Context` consistently through Cobra → command handlers → k8s/maintenance/tui.

## Problem
`initializeGlobals` creates a signal-aware context via `signal.NotifyContext(context.Background(), ...)` but never attaches it to Cobra (`cmd.SetContext(ctx)`), and some commands ignore `cmd.Context()`.

Known locations:
- Root pre-run: `cmd/crook/commands/root.go:81-86`
- Context creation: `cmd/crook/commands/root.go:123-126`
- `crook ls` uses `context.Background()` instead of cobra context: `cmd/crook/commands/ls.go:144`

## Impact
- Ctrl+C may not cancel long-running operations (poll loops, waits, watch mode, TUI background refreshes).
- Timeouts in down/up wrap the wrong base context.
- Harder to build reliable automation (can’t reliably abort).

## Expected behavior
- `cmd.Context()` for all subcommands is cancellable by SIGINT/SIGTERM.
- All downstream calls (k8s client operations, maintenance waits, watch loops, TUI refresh loops) use the same root context.

## References
- `openspec/project.md` (context-based cancellation)
design:
Proposed fix:
- In `initializeGlobals`, call `cmd.SetContext(ctx)` and also store on `GlobalOptions` if still needed.
- Ensure `cleanup()` cancels and that background goroutines respect ctx.Done().
- Update `crook ls` to accept/pass context from Cobra.
acceptance_criteria:
- Ctrl+C cancels `crook down`, `crook up`, `crook ls` (including `--watch`) quickly
- All commands use `cmd.Context()` as the root context; no `context.Background()` in command handlers
- Unit tests cover that root pre-run sets a non-background, cancelable context
notes:
Implementation checklist:
- Update `cmd/crook/commands/root.go` to set command context.
- Refactor `runLs` to accept `ctx` (and wire from cmd.Context()).
- Audit other command handlers for `context.Background()`.
- Add tests: create root cmd, execute a trivial subcommand, assert `cmd.Context()` is not `context.Background()` (e.g., has a deadline/cancel func), and that `cleanup()` cancels it.

title: Revisit pkg/k8s global client cache (avoid wrong-cluster reuse)
description:
## Context
`pkg/k8s` currently has a global singleton client (`GetClient`) which can be convenient but is risky when different kubeconfigs/contexts are used.

## Problem
Global caching is currently a single pointer with no keying. If different call sites create clients with different settings, the cached client can be reused incorrectly.

## Impact
- Wrong-cluster reuse risk if codepaths use different kubeconfig/context.
- Makes tests order-dependent.
- Contributes to command inconsistency (ls vs down/up).

## Expected behavior
- Either no global singleton at all (preferred), or a cache keyed by effective kubeconfig/context/in-cluster mode.

## References
- `openspec/project.md` (dependency injection / avoid globals)
design:
Design options:
1) Remove global client: delete `GetClient` usage and pass client explicitly.
2) Keep cache but key it by `kubeconfigPath + contextName + inCluster` and return distinct clients per key; add eviction/limits if necessary.
acceptance_criteria:
- Client reuse cannot cross kubeconfig/context boundaries
- `crook ls`, `crook down`, and `crook up` use a consistent client creation strategy
- Tests cover the chosen behavior (no-cache or keyed cache)
notes:
Notes:
- If removing cache, update call sites (not just commands) that rely on it.
- If keeping cache, make it safe for concurrent access and tests.

title: Make crook ls use GlobalOptions config + cobra context (no re-load)
description:
## Context
All commands should respect the same merged configuration (defaults + file + env + flags) and should target the same kubeconfig/context for a given invocation.

## Problem
`crook ls` re-loads config and uses a different client creation path than `crook down/up`.

Current behavior:
- `crook down/up` use `GlobalOptions.Config` and `k8s.NewClient(ctx, {Kubeconfig, Context})`.
- `crook ls` does its own `config.LoadConfig(config.LoadOptions{})` and uses `k8s.GetClient(ctx, k8s.ClientConfig{})`.

Code:
- Config reload: `cmd/crook/commands/ls.go:147-152`
- Client creation: `cmd/crook/commands/ls.go:154-157`

## Impact
- `crook ls` can target a different cluster/context than `crook down/up`.
- Root flags like `--config` / `--kubeconfig` / `--namespace` can appear to work for down/up but not for ls.

## Expected behavior
- `crook ls` uses the same effective config (`GlobalOptions.Config`).
- Client creation is consistent with down/up for kubeconfig/context selection.
- Context is passed from Cobra so Ctrl+C works.

## References
- `openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/specs/configuration/spec.md`
design:
Proposed fix:
- Change `runLs` to accept `ctx context.Context` and `cfg config.Config` from `GlobalOptions`.
- Create client via `k8s.NewClient` using `cfg.Kubernetes.{Kubeconfig,Context}`.
- Remove per-command config reload unless there’s a strong reason.
acceptance_criteria:
- `crook ls` honors `--config`, env overrides, and all root flag bindings
- `crook ls` uses `cmd.Context()` and cancels on Ctrl+C
- `crook ls` client selection matches `crook down/up` for kubeconfig/context
notes:
Notes / test plan:
- Add command-level tests to confirm that setting `--kubeconfig` affects `ls` (can be validated by ensuring error message includes the path when missing).
- Add tests ensuring `runLs` doesn’t call `config.LoadConfig` (via refactor/injection or by ensuring GlobalOptions is used).
- Coordinate with `crook-5nh.10` if global caching remains a concern.

title: Allow crook config validate to run even when config is invalid
description:

2) Move config loading out of root pre-run into individual commands (shared helper) and keep root pre-run for context/signal setup only.

title: Close log file handle on cleanup (avoid FD leak)
description:
## Problem
`initLogger` opens a log file when `logging.file` is set, but the file handle is never closed.

design:

title: Harden down/up non-TUI confirmation + use cobra IO writers
description:
## Context
Non-TUI down/up modes prompt for confirmation unless automation flags are set.

## Problem
Prompt reading uses `fmt.Scanln(&response)`, which treats an empty Enter as an error. Also, command IO bypasses Cobra streams.

Code
- Prompt read: `cmd/crook/commands/down.go:171-179`, `cmd/crook/commands/up.go:177-185`
- Output hard-coded to `os.Stdout`: `cmd/crook/commands/down.go:155`, `cmd/crook/commands/up.go:161`
- `printLine` requires `*os.File`: `cmd/crook/commands/down.go:211-213`

## Impact
- UX bug: pressing Enter can produce an error instead of a clean abort.
- Harder to test and integrate because `cmd.SetOut/SetIn` isn’t respected.

## Expected behavior
- Empty input should be treated as default No and abort cleanly.
- Commands should use `cmd.InOrStdin()` and `cmd.OutOrStdout()` / `cmd.ErrOrStderr()`.
design:
Proposed fix:
- Replace `fmt.Scanln` with a buffered reader (`bufio.Reader`) and parse a full line.

title: Remove global k8s client singleton; plumb config-derived client
description:
## Problem
`pkg/k8s` maintains a process-wide `globalClient` (`pkg/k8s/client.go:34`) and exposes many package-level helpers that implicitly call `GetClient(ctx, ClientConfig{})` (e.g. `pkg/k8s/pods.go:53`, `pkg/k8s/deployments.go:46`). This causes:
- First-call-wins config bug: once `globalClient` is created, future calls ignore `ClientConfig` (kubeconfig path/context).
- Commands that load config can still silently ignore kubeconfig/context because they call `k8s.GetClient(ctx, k8s.ClientConfig{})` (e.g. `cmd/crook/commands/ls.go:154`).
- Violates project convention “pass dependencies explicitly (no global state)” (`openspec/project.md`).

## Desired behavior
- The CLI creates exactly one `*k8s.Client` per invocation using config-derived kubeconfig/context and passes it down (DI).
- No hidden global state in `pkg/k8s` that changes behavior based on call order.

## Proposed approach
- Deprecate/remove `globalClient`, `GetClient`, `SetGlobalClient`, and package-level wrappers that implicitly call them.
- Introduce an explicit constructor/factory called by commands (likely in `cmd/crook/commands/*`), using config values.
- Keep `*k8s.Client` methods as the primary API.

## Tasks
- Inventory all callers of package-level k8s functions; convert them to use an injected `*k8s.Client`.
- Ensure config loading produces `k8s.ClientConfig` (kubeconfig path + context) and commands wire it through.
- Update tests to use explicit client injection (fake clientsets) without touching globals.

## Acceptance criteria
- No package-level functions in `pkg/k8s` create hidden clients with empty config in production codepaths.
- `crook ls` and maintenance commands use configured kubeconfig/context.
- Running `go test ./...` passes.

## Notes
This is a prerequisite for other hardening work (RBAC scoping, retry correctness) to behave predictably.

title: Scope pod discovery to namespace (avoid all-namespaces Pods(""))
description:
## Problem
`ListPodsOnNode` lists pods across *all namespaces* via `Pods("")` (`pkg/k8s/pods.go:38`). The maintenance discovery path calls this (`pkg/maintenance/discovery.go:28`).

This conflicts with:
- Least-privilege RBAC expectations (cluster-wide pod list often forbidden).
- The operational reference behavior in `osd-maintenance.sh`, which scopes discovery to `ROOK_CLUSTER_NAMESPACE`.
- Performance: listing all pods in the cluster is expensive on large clusters.

## Desired behavior
- Maintenance discovery should only require listing pods in the configured Rook cluster namespace.
- Any all-namespaces listing should be avoided or be an explicit opt-in for admin-only features.

## Proposed approach
- Change/replace `ListPodsOnNode` to accept a namespace and list pods only within that namespace using a field selector.
- Update `pkg/maintenance/discovery.go` to use the namespaced variant.
- For any `ls` UX that truly needs cross-namespace data, add a separate explicit function and document RBAC requirements.

## Tasks
- Add `ListPodsOnNodeInNamespace(ctx, namespace, nodeName)` or change signature.
- Update discovery codepaths and tests.
- Document required RBAC verbs/Resources for each command path.

## Acceptance criteria
- Discovery for down/up works with namespace-scoped RBAC (no cluster-wide pod list).
- Behavior matches `osd-maintenance.sh` namespace scoping.
- Tests cover “forbidden to list all namespaces” scenario (fake client + reactor).

## Dependencies

title: Fix retry classification for wrapped Kubernetes API errors
description:
## Problem
`WithRetry` depends on `isRetryable`/`getRetryAfter` using direct type assertions to `*apierrors.StatusError` (`pkg/k8s/retry.go:93`, `pkg/k8s/retry.go:119`). Most call sites wrap errors with `%w`, so the assertion fails, and the code falls back to treating the error as a generic retryable network error (`pkg/k8s/retry.go:111`).

This can cause incorrect behavior such as retrying hard failures (403 Forbidden, 404 NotFound, validation errors) simply because they were wrapped.

## Desired behavior
- Retry logic must correctly detect Kubernetes API status codes even through wrapped errors.
- Do not retry non-transient failures.

## Proposed approach
- Use `errors.As` to unwrap `*apierrors.StatusError`.
- Use `errors.Is` for `context.Canceled` / `context.DeadlineExceeded` (also through wrapping).
- Tighten the non-StatusError fallback to retry only for known transient net/http errors (timeouts, temporary, connection reset), not “everything”.
- Keep `Retry-After` extraction best-effort, but base it on unwrapped `StatusError`.

## Tasks
- Refactor `isRetryable` and `getRetryAfter` to use unwrapping.
- Add tests that wrap `StatusError` with `%w` and ensure behavior stays correct.
- Audit call sites to ensure errors are wrapped with `%w` (consistent with `openspec/project.md`).

## Acceptance criteria
- Wrapped 403/404 errors are not retried.
- Wrapped 429/5xx errors are retried.
- Unit tests demonstrate the wrapped-error cases.

## Dependencies
- Can be implemented independently, but should land before adding retries to more operations (e.g., scaling).

title: Fix/rename deployment wait helpers: WaitForReplicas currently checks spec, not status
description:
## Problem
`WaitForReplicas` checks `deployment.Spec.Replicas` (`pkg/k8s/deployments.go:139`), which typically matches immediately after issuing a scale request. The operational reference (`osd-maintenance.sh`) waits on `.status.replicas` / readiness changes and uses ready-replicas-empty behavior for scale-to-zero.

This means:
- `WaitForReplicas` may return success before Kubernetes has actually applied the scale / created or removed pods.
- Callers may proceed assuming state changes have completed.

## Desired behavior
- Wait helpers should match their names and the operational intent:
  - wait for observed replicas (`status.replicas`) and/or ready replicas.
  - support scale-to-zero semantics consistent with the script.

## Proposed approach
Option A (recommended):
- Rename current `WaitForReplicas` to `WaitForSpecReplicas`.
- Add `WaitForStatusReplicas` that checks `deployment.Status.Replicas`.
- Keep `WaitForReadyReplicas` for ready counts.

Option B:
- Change `WaitForReplicas` to check `deployment.Status.Replicas` (breaking behavior change) and update call sites/tests.

## Tasks
- Decide API surface (A vs B) and update call sites in maintenance.
- Add tests covering:
  - scale-to-zero: status/ready reach 0.
  - scale-up: status reaches desired and ready reaches desired.

## Acceptance criteria
- Wait functions do not return early while pods are still terminating/starting.
- Behavior aligns with `osd-maintenance.sh` waiting logic.

## Dependencies
- None strictly, but pairs well with improved retry logic (`crook-8nb.3`) for polling and transient API errors.

title: NodeExists should use apierrors.IsNotFound (not string matching)
description:
## Problem
`NodeExists` uses `strings.Contains(err.Error(), "not found")` to detect NotFound (`pkg/k8s/nodes.go:289`). This is brittle and locale/version dependent.

## Desired behavior
- Use Kubernetes API error helpers for correctness: `apierrors.IsNotFound(err)` (or `k8s.IsNotFound` wrapper).

## Tasks
- Replace string matching with `apierrors.IsNotFound`.
- Add/adjust unit test to cover NotFound vs other errors.

## Acceptance criteria
- NodeExists returns (false, nil) only for actual NotFound.
- Other errors return (false, wrapped error).

title: Unify empty-prefix filtering semantics across k8s helpers
description:
## Problem
Prefix filtering behavior is inconsistent:
- `matchesAnyPrefix` returns false when `prefixes` is empty (`pkg/k8s/nodes.go:279`), causing `ListNodesWithCephPods` to report 0 Ceph pods everywhere when prefixes are not configured (`pkg/k8s/nodes.go:195`).
- Other filters treat empty as “match all” (e.g., `FilterDeploymentsByPrefix`, `matchesPodPrefix`).

## Desired behavior
- Empty prefixes should have consistent meaning across the package (recommended: empty == match all).

## Tasks
- Decide and document consistent semantics (prefer match-all).
- Update helper(s) and any callers that relied on the old behavior.
- Add unit tests for empty-prefix behavior on nodes/pods/deployments list helpers.

## Acceptance criteria
- With empty prefixes, `ls` views still show meaningful pod counts and resources.
- No regressions in existing tests.

title: ScaleDeployment should use scale subresource/patch + add conflict-aware retry
description:
## Problem
`ScaleDeployment` performs a full Deployment GET + Update to set `spec.replicas` (`pkg/k8s/deployments.go:24`). This is:
- Conflict-prone (resourceVersion races) under concurrent controllers/actors.
- Heavier than needed (updates full object instead of scale subresource).
- Not currently using retry/backoff.

## Desired behavior
- Use the scale subresource (`UpdateScale`) or a minimal patch to `spec.replicas`.
- Handle transient conflicts / API server errors with correct retry behavior.

## Proposed approach
- Implement `ScaleDeployment` using `AppsV1().Deployments(ns).UpdateScale(...)` or JSON merge/strategic patch.
- On `Conflict`, re-fetch and retry (or rely on generic retry once `crook-8nb.3` is fixed).

## Tasks
- Switch implementation to scale subresource/patch.
- Add unit tests for:
  - happy path replica change
  - conflict retry behavior (fake client reactor)
- Consider integrating `WithRetry` once it correctly classifies wrapped errors.

## Acceptance criteria
- Scaling is robust under conflicts.
- No unnecessary object updates.

## Dependencies
- Should land after retry fix (`crook-8nb.3`) if using shared retry helper.

title: Tighten Ceph command execution surface (ExecuteCephCommand/ExecInPod)
description:
## Problem
`ExecInPod` can execute arbitrary commands in any pod/container (`pkg/k8s/pods.go:155`). `ExecuteCephCommand` accepts a raw `command []string` and forwards it to exec (`pkg/k8s/ceph.go:45`), despite its name implying Ceph-only usage.

This increases the blast radius if a higher-level caller ever passes unsanitized user input, and it makes it harder to reason about what the tool can do.

## Desired behavior
- Prefer narrow, high-level APIs for Ceph interactions (set/unset flags, query status/df/quorum/osd tree).
- If a generic exec is required, keep it internal and/or enforce constraints.

## Proposed approach
- Change Ceph API to accept args only and prepend `ceph` internally (i.e., `ExecuteCeph(ctx, ns, args...)`).
- Validate that the first element is `ceph` if keeping `ExecuteCephCommand`.
- Consider making `ExecInPod` unexported or moving it behind an interface used only where needed.

## Tasks
- Inventory call sites to see whether any user input can reach `ExecInPod`/`ExecuteCephCommand`.
- Apply API tightening, update call sites and tests.
- Document remaining command execution capabilities and RBAC needs.

## Acceptance criteria
- It is not possible to run non-Ceph commands via the exported Ceph API.
- Command execution surface is explicit and auditable.

title: Reduce API load + improve asymptotic behavior in ls helpers
description:
## Problem
Some ls helpers have potentially high API/server cost on large clusters:
- `ListCephPods` calls `GetOwnerChain` per pod, which can trigger ReplicaSet GETs (`pkg/k8s/pods.go`, `pkg/k8s/pods.go:62`).
- `ListCephDeployments` does an O(pods × deployments) scan to map deployments to nodes (`pkg/k8s/deployments.go:278`).

These are fine for small clusters but can become slow/noisy.

## Desired behavior
- Keep the ls path responsive and low-impact.

## Possible approaches
- Avoid per-pod GETs by deriving deployment from ReplicaSet name (best-effort) and/or using label selectors.
- Build a single map from ReplicaSet prefix -> deployment, and then map pods to deployments in one pass.
- Add caching within a single fetch cycle.

## Tasks
- Profile ls data fetch in a large cluster (or synthetic benchmark) to identify hotspots.
- Implement a lower-cost owner resolution strategy with clear best-effort semantics.
- Add tests for name parsing edge cases.

## Acceptance criteria
- ls fetch performs O(pods + deployments) work (not O(pods × deployments)).
- No additional API calls per pod in the common case.

title: P0: Up phase must ensure MON quorum before scaling OSDs
description:
## Problem
The Node Maintenance spec explicitly requires the up phase to ensure monitors establish quorum before scaling OSDs:
- `openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/specs/node-maintenance/spec.md:78`

Current implementation only orders deployments (`mon` before `osd`) and waits on Kubernetes readiness, but does not verify Ceph monitor quorum before proceeding.

## Evidence

## Proposed Fix
- After scaling MON deployments (and waiting for readiness), explicitly verify quorum via Ceph:
  - Option A: run `ceph status --format json` via rook-ceph-tools and ensure monitors are in quorum.
  - Option B: run `ceph quorum_status --format json` (if available) and check quorum membership.
- Only proceed to scaling OSD deployments once quorum is confirmed.
- Add retry/backoff + timeout aligned with existing wait options.
- Ensure behavior is safe under partial restores (e.g. SkipMissingDeployments): if MON deployment missing, fail safe and do not scale OSDs.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Up phase blocks OSD scaling until MON quorum is confirmed.
- Failure mode is actionable (message includes what quorum check failed and how to inspect manually).
- Unit tests cover ordering + quorum gate (fake exec output).

## References

- `pkg/k8s/ceph.go` (ceph command execution)
- `openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/specs/node-maintenance/spec.md`

description:
## Problem

- Backup existing state file before overwrite.
- Missing state file error message format.
- State file age warning + confirmation gate.

Some of this is implemented in `pkg/state` (backup + validation), but `pkg/maintenance` is not using it.

## Evidence

- `pkg/maintenance/up.go:93` uses `state.ParseFile` directly (no `ValidateFile` warnings/age checks).
- Spec: `openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/specs/state-persistence/spec.md:94`

title: Fix deployment health semantics and aggregation severity
description:
## Problem
Deployment monitoring and aggregation logic can report misleading health, especially during maintenance when deployments are intentionally scaled to 0.

## Evidence
- `pkg/monitoring/deployments.go:88` `determineDeploymentHealth` marks any deployment with `AvailableReplicas == 0` as `Unavailable` (`pkg/monitoring/deployments.go:109`), even when desired replicas are 0.
  - Spec requires Unavailable only when `ready replicas == 0` and `desired > 0` (`openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/specs/cluster-monitoring/spec.md:132`).
- `pkg/monitoring/deployments.go:135` `MonitorDeployments` silently drops per-deployment errors; if all deployments fail to fetch, it returns `OverallStatus=Ready` with an empty list (`pkg/monitoring/deployments.go:159`).
- Aggregation treats `DeploymentUnavailable` as a critical condition (`pkg/monitoring/aggregation.go:261`), but spec defines "Critical" only for `node NotReady` or `Ceph HEALTH_ERR` (`openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/specs/cluster-monitoring/spec.md:193`).

## Impact
- During down-phase operations, intentionally-scaled deployments can appear "critical" and may block workflows or mislead operators.
- Missing deployments (RBAC/typo) can be shown as "Healthy".

## Proposed direction
- Update deployment health classification:
  - If `desired == 0`: treat as a distinct "ScaledDown" state or at least not `Unavailable`.
  - Apply the spec rule for `Unavailable` only when `desired > 0`.
- Return error/unknown state when 0/N deployments were successfully fetched.
- Revisit aggregation: deployment/operator unavailability should likely be "Degraded" unless explicitly defined as critical.

## Acceptance criteria
- Deployments with desired=0 are not labeled `Unavailable`.
- `MonitorDeployments` indicates missing data (error or unknown) when it cannot fetch any requested deployments.
- Aggregation severity matches cluster-monitoring spec.
- Unit tests cover scaled-to-zero and missing-data cases.

title: Add per-monitor error propagation + logging for refresh failures
description:
## Problem

- `MonitorUpdate.Error` exists but is never set (`pkg/monitoring/monitor.go:45`).
- Spec: on refresh error, log + continue retry + display stale data with last-updated indicator (`openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/specs/cluster-monitoring/spec.md:150`).

## Proposed direction
- Add structured logging via `internal/logger` at the point where a monitor decides to suppress an error.
- Surface per-component error state:

title: Fix monitor lifecycle: respect ctx + validate intervals
description:
## Problem
`pkg/monitoring`'s monitoring lifecycle ignores the caller-provided context and can panic or misbehave with invalid refresh intervals.

## Evidence
- `pkg/monitoring/monitor.go:231` `StartMonitoring(ctx, ...)` accepts `ctx` but never uses it; `NewMonitor` always derives from `context.Background()` (`pkg/monitoring/monitor.go:68`).
- All polling loops create tickers without validating `interval` (`time.NewTicker(interval)`), which panics for `<= 0` and violates the OpenSpec requirement to validate intervals and warn on aggressive values:
  - `pkg/monitoring/node.go:95`
  - `pkg/monitoring/ceph.go:126`
  - `pkg/monitoring/ceph.go:318`
  - `pkg/monitoring/deployments.go:176`
  - Spec: `openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/specs/cluster-monitoring/spec.md:158`.

## Impact
- Callers cannot stop monitoring via their own `ctx` (only via `Monitor.Stop()`), which is a footgun for Bubble Tea model lifecycles and Ctrl+C handling.
- Invalid config can crash the process (ticker panic).

## Proposed direction
- Thread `ctx` into `NewMonitor` (or make `NewMonitor` accept `ctx`), and ensure `StartMonitoring` derives monitor context from the caller.
- Validate `NodeRefreshInterval`, `CephRefreshInterval`, `DeploymentRefreshInterval` are `>= 1s` per spec; warn (log) if `< 1s`.
- Decide policy for `0` values: either treat as "use defaults" or reject with error.

## Acceptance criteria
- `StartMonitoring` and `Monitor` honor a caller `ctx` (cancellation stops all monitor goroutines).
- Interval validation implemented; no `time.NewTicker` panics from configuration.
- Unit tests cover invalid/too-aggressive interval behavior.

title: Default state backup directory uses ~ but is not expanded (writes backups to ./~/...)
description:
Problem:
- `pkg/config/config.go` sets `state.backup-directory` default to `~/.local/state/crook/backups`.
- `pkg/state/backup.go` uses `opts.Directory` verbatim with `os.MkdirAll`, but does not expand `~`.
- Result: running with defaults can create a literal `./~/.local/state/crook/backups` directory (relative to CWD) and place backups there, contrary to docs and operator expectations.

Why it matters:
- Surprising/incorrect default behavior; backups can end up in the wrong place.
- Potentially dangerous if CWD is unexpected (e.g., running from `/etc` or a mounted path).

Spec/Docs references:
- `crook.yaml.example` documents default backup dir as `~/.local/state/crook/backups`.

Suggested fix:
- Expand `~` (and ideally env vars) for `BackupOptions.Directory` in `pkg/state/backup.go` (preferred: keep state package self-contained), OR normalize/expand in config loading before passing into state.
- Add/adjust tests to assert default backup directory resolves to `$HOME/.local/state/crook/backups`.

Acceptance criteria:
- With default config, backups are created under the user home directory, not under `./~`.
- Unit test covers `BackupOptions.Directory` containing `~`.
- No behavior regression when `Directory` is empty (fallback to `<path>.backup.<ts>.json`).

Why it matters:
- Spec/design calls out env var overrides; operators may want to tune prefixes in automation.

Acceptance criteria:

title: Harden state file template placeholder validation (avoid regex-based parsing edge cases)
description:
Problem:
- `pkg/config/validation.go` validates state file templates by:
  - parsing with `text/template`, then
  - using a regex `{{[^}]*}}` to find placeholders and requiring the inner text be exactly `.Node`.

Risks/downsides:
- Regex placeholder detection is not a proper template parser and can mis-handle legitimate template syntax (e.g., whitespace trimming actions like `{{- .Node -}}`).
- Error messages can be confusing for users who write slightly different but equivalent templates.

Acceptance criteria:
- Either explicitly document the exact allowed template syntax (`{{.Node}}` only, no trimming), OR
- Replace regex-based inspection with AST-based inspection (walk `template.Tree` nodes) and allow safe variants (whitespace trim).
- Unit tests cover at least:
  - `./crook-state-{{.Node}}.json` (valid)
  - `./crook-state-{{- .Node -}}.json` (valid if supported)
  - an unknown placeholder (invalid)
  - malformed template (invalid)

title: Expand ~ / env vars for path-like config fields (logging.file, state.file-path-template override paths, etc.)
description:
Problem:
- Several config fields represent filesystem paths and are documented with `~` examples (e.g., `crook.yaml.example` uses `~/.kube/config` and suggests `~/.local/state/crook/crook.log`).
- `pkg/config/validation.go` expands `~` only for `kubernetes.kubeconfig`.
- `cmd/crook/commands/root.go` opens `cfg.Logging.File` verbatim; `~` is not expanded and will fail or write to an unexpected relative path.
- `pkg/config/loader.go` / validation do not normalize/expand `state.backup-directory` (covered by `crook-ztw.1`) and do not validate that `logging.file` is writable.

Desired behavior:
- Treat `~` and `$VARS` consistently across all path-like config values.

Suggested approach:
- Centralize expansion/normalization in one helper (either in `pkg/config` as a pure function, or in each consumer with consistent semantics).
- Define which fields get expansion:
  - `kubernetes.kubeconfig`
  - `state.backup-directory`
  - `logging.file`
  - any CLI override path flags (e.g. `--state-file`)

Acceptance criteria:
- `logging.file: ~/.local/state/crook/crook.log` works.
- Expansion behavior is documented (what gets expanded, what does not).
- Unit tests cover `~` and `$HOME` cases for each supported field.

title: Detect/ban unknown config keys (avoid silent typos via strict unmarshal or unused-key checks)
description:
Problem:
- `pkg/config/loader.go` uses `v.Unmarshal(&cfg)` which ignores unknown keys.
- Typos in config files or env vars can silently fall back to defaults, which is risky for an ops tool.

Examples:
- `rook-operator-namesapce` (typo) is ignored and default `rook-ceph` is used.

Options:
- Use `v.UnmarshalExact(&cfg)` (fails on unknown keys), OR
- Implement an explicit unused-key check using `v.AllSettings()` + schema walk, then surface as validation errors/warnings.

Spec/Intent:
- Matches the safety goal of a guided maintenance tool; aligns with `openspec/changes/add-go-tui-interface/design.md` emphasis on safer operations.

Acceptance criteria:
- Unknown keys cause `crook config validate` to report a clear error listing the unknown keys.
- Tests cover unknown top-level key and unknown nested key.
- Behavior for the special `namespace` override is explicitly decided:
  - either add it to the schema (so it is not an unknown key), or restrict it to CLI-only (so config/env can’t set it).

title: Make LoadConfig validation failures actionable (typed error or include validation details in error string)
description:
Problem:
- On validation failure, `pkg/config/loader.go` returns `error("configuration validation failed")` without attaching the specific validation errors.
- `cmd/crook/commands/root.go` surfaces only the generic message, so `crook <command>` can fail at startup without telling the operator what to fix (unless they separately run `crook config validate`).

Suggested approach:
- Introduce an exported error type (e.g., `type ValidationError struct { Result ValidationResult }`) implementing `Error()` and optionally `Unwrap()`.
- Return that error from `LoadConfig` so callers can print structured issues (and still have a stable generic string if needed).

Acceptance criteria:
- Running `crook down ...` with an invalid config yields an error that includes the specific failing fields.
- `crook config validate` output remains stable and well-formatted.
- Unit tests cover the error behavior (string contains at least one validation error message).

title: Expand config validation to cover log/theme/refresh values (avoid silent fallbacks and busy loops)
description:
Gaps:
- `pkg/config/validation.go` does not validate:
  - `logging.level` (allowed: debug/info/warn/error)
  - `logging.format` (allowed: text/json)
  - `ui.theme` (currently only default is supported)
  - UI refresh rates for non-positive values (0 or negative currently only produces a warning, not an error)
  - `state.backup-enabled` + `state.backup-directory` interplay (if directory is set, ensure node is available at call site, or ensure expansion/normalization)

Why it matters:
- Invalid values currently degrade silently (e.g., unknown log level becomes info in `cmd/crook/commands/root.go`).
- Non-positive refresh intervals can lead to tight loops or excessive API calls in background polling.

Acceptance criteria:
- Invalid `logging.level` / `logging.format` / `ui.theme` becomes validation error with an allowed-values list.
- `ui.*-refresh-ms` must be >= 100ms (or a clearly defined minimum) and error on <=0.
- Tests cover at least one invalid value per field.

title: Improve kubeconfig path validation errors (don’t collapse permission/dir errors into “not found”)
description:
Problem:
- `pkg/config/validation.go:validateKubeconfigPath` returns `kubeconfig file not found` for most error cases, including permission errors, homedir resolution errors, and non-ENOENT stat failures.
- It also reports directories as “not found”, which is misleading.

Why it matters:
- Operators need precise feedback to resolve cluster access issues quickly.

Acceptance criteria:
- Distinguish at least:
  - does not exist
  - is a directory
  - permission denied / other stat errors
  - `~` expansion failures
- Error messages include the resolved path when relevant.
- Unit tests cover permission denied (can be simulated by chmod 000 on a temp file/dir) and directory path cases.

title: Extend default config file discovery to include .toml/.yml (spec says YAML/TOML)
description:
Problem:
- `pkg/config/loader.go:defaultConfigFiles()` only searches `./crook.yaml`, `~/.config/crook/config.yaml`, and `/etc/crook/config.yaml`.
- The design proposal mentions YAML/TOML configs; operators may reasonably expect `crook.toml` / `config.toml` to be discovered as well.

Acceptance criteria:
- Default discovery checks common variants in a clearly documented order, e.g.:
  - `./crook.yaml`, `./crook.yml`, `./crook.toml`
  - `~/.config/crook/config.yaml`, `.yml`, `.toml`
  - `/etc/crook/config.yaml`, `.yml`, `.toml`
- Tests cover discovery order with multiple present files.
- Documentation updated (`crook.yaml.example` header comment or CLI help text) to match actual behavior.

title: Clarify/solidify namespace override semantics (namespace vs rook-operator-namespace/rook-cluster-namespace)
description:
Current behavior:
- `pkg/config/loader.go` binds `--namespace` to viper key `namespace` (not part of the config schema).
- `applyNamespaceOverride` always overwrites both `kubernetes.rook-operator-namespace` and `kubernetes.rook-cluster-namespace` if `namespace` is set from any source (flags, env, or config file).

Issues:
- Hidden config surface area: `namespace` can be set via env/config but will not appear in `crook config show` output.
- If per-namespace flags are added later, precedence may be surprising (shared namespace overwrites explicit ones).

Acceptance criteria:
- Decide and implement one of:
  1) Make `namespace` CLI-only (do not allow env/config to set it; document), OR
  2) Add `namespace` to the config schema/output so it is visible and validated, OR
  3) Apply override only when operator/cluster namespace are unset (explicit values win).
- Add tests for the chosen semantics.
- Update CLI help and/or `crook.yaml.example` to reflect the decision.

title: Avoid exported mutable DefaultDeploymentPrefixes (risk of unexpected mutation/races)
description:
Problem:
- `pkg/config/config.go` exposes `var DefaultDeploymentPrefixes = []string{...}`.
- Because it is exported and mutable, any consumer can mutate it (intentionally or accidentally), changing defaults globally and potentially introducing data races.

Suggested approaches:
- Make it unexported (breaking change for external consumers), and expose a function `DefaultDeploymentPrefixes() []string` returning a copy.
- Or keep the exported name but return a copy and deprecate mutation (e.g., document it as read-only and add a getter).

Acceptance criteria:
- Defaults cannot be mutated by external packages (or mutation is clearly deprecated and guarded).
- `DefaultConfig()` continues to return independent slices.
- Add a test that attempting to modify the returned prefixes from `DefaultConfig()` does not affect subsequent `DefaultConfig()` calls.
